Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: The production and perception of breathy voice during nasal sounds

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Language users often adjust or enhance their speech to be better understood in different contexts, such as when speaking in a loud room, or to a person with an accent, or when speaking on the phone. The study of speech enhancement strategies addresses important questions about human language, including how language is perceived by listeners and represented in the mind. Answering these questions is also vital to both speech therapy and speech technology. For speech therapy, this understanding can improve methods used in diagnosis and treatment of disordered speech. For speech technology, this understanding can improve speech recognition and synthesis, which are both used daily by the public, such as when calling a company's customer service. Knowledge of the way we enhance speech also helps researchers understand how and why languages change over time. This understanding is crucial for educating the public on linguistic diversity, change, and preservation.

This research seeks to understand what enhancements occur when making nasal sounds, which are found in almost all languages of the world, including American English. Nasality is a common feature associated with an individual's voice: in any language, some speakers sound more nasal than others. This research focuses on how the voice is used to make sounds nasal. First, the researchers investigate whether speakers of American English and Brazilian Portuguese produce nasals with voice adjustments from the larynx. Second, they investigate how the perception of voice influences the perception of nasal sounds. These two languages differ in their use of nasal sounds, and so together they provide a better understanding of how different types of nasal sounds are made in different languages. This knowledge will help clarify how this particular type of sound is produced and perceived, which has the potential to improve techniques used to treat disordered speech as well as software used in speech recognition and synthesis.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The purpose of this work was to investigate whether breathy voice quality is produced and/or perceived during nasalized vowels. Although the articulation of nasalization is distinct from that of breathy voice (velum lowering vs. vocal fold manipulation), both of these gestures share acoustic similarities (increased spectral tilt and dampened energy; Chen, 1997; Klatt & Klatt, 1990; Styler, 2017). 

Specifically, this project investigated whether American English (AE) and Brazilian Portuguese (BP) speakers produced breathy voice quality during nasalized vowels, and whether they perceived vowels as more nasal when acoustic cues related to breathiness were present. This would imply that the acoustic attributes shared by nasalization and breathy voice quality interact in speech production and perception, which in turn could help explain various sound changes attested in languages of the world.

In order to determine whether AE and BP speakers produced vowel nasalization with a breathy voice quality, we used electroglottography to indirectly measure vocal fold articulation. In general, we found that both AE and BP speakers produce a breathier voice quality during nasalized vowels.  One measure, Contact Quotient (CQ), revealed that vowels were produced with more breathiness when the consonant preceding the vowel was nasal. Interestingly, the opposite effect was found for the consonant following the vowel: when the consonant following the vowel was nasal, vowels were produced with less breathiness. Further, when BP vowels were nasal, they were produced with less breathiness than oral vowels preceded by a nasal consonant. This would imply that the preceding nasal consonant induces breathy voice on following vowels that are oral. 

In the perception study, the listener heard a spoken word and then had to identify it by choosing between two words that were minimally contrasted by a nasal sound. We measured whether a listener was fasterand more likely to choose the nasal word when acoustic cues associated with breathiness (higher spectral tilt and increased noise) were present. 

In AE, increased cues to breathiness were significant predictors for word choice (whether or not the listener chose a nasal or non-nasal word). These predictors were also significant for reaction time (how fast a listener was to make a choice). Listeners were significantly faster to choose a nasal word when the vowel contained additional cues to breathiness. Additionally, listeners were significantly slower to choose a non-nasal word when the vowel was breathier. Thus, it appears that AE listeners associated cues to breathiness with nasalization. 

For BP, increased cues to breathiness did not seem to have a strong effect on word choice or reaction time. For word choice, listeners were more likely to choose a non-nasal word when there were no additional cues to breathiness. Reaction time results were marginally significant. Listeners were generally faster to choose a nasal word when the vowel contained some cues to breathiness.

Taken together, these studies provide evidence that (1) both AE and BP speakers may articulate nasalized vowels with a breathier voice quality and (2) that AE (and to an extent, BP) listeners may use acoustic correlates associated with breathiness to perceive words with nasalization. More broadly, these results support recent research (Garellek, Ritchart & Kuang, 2016; Carignan, 2017) which implies that nasalization is multidimensional in its articulation and that it may be perceptually enhanced through breathy voice (Carignan, 2017; Stevens & Keyser, 2010).

These results are important to the study of linguistics for several reasons. First, this research helps us better understand the role of sound enhancement in sound change, such as why oral vowels in a language may become phonologically nasal over time. Second, this research allows us to compare different models of speaker-driven and listener-driven accounts of sound change. For example, the fact that increased breathiness helps AE speakers more quickly choose nasal words may lend support to a listener-driven account of sound change. In this account, listeners may misperceive nasalization as breathiness, which eventually results in nasal sounds becoming breathy but non-nasal. 

The results of this research also have broader implications. In general, we now have a deeper understanding of how nasalization -- a feature found in nearly all of the world's languages (Maddieson, 2008) -- is produced and perceived by speakers. Such knowledge is important for research on speech disorders involving nasalization, such as resonance disorders and velopharyngeal dysfunction. For example, clinical treatment for AE and BP speakers might be improved by incorporating breathy voice in nasal production, especially in individuals with hyponasality. For those with hypernasality, a more pressed voice quality (i.e., less breathiness) could be incorporated in treatment.
